text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits new IRM 1.20.4, Civil Rights, Prevention of Taxpayer Discrimination.

This new IRM 1.20.4, provides guidance for providing reasonable accommodations to taxpayers, ensuring language access to programs, activities, and services, and explains when to refer taxpayers to the discrimination complaint process.
The audience for this IRM is managers and employees having taxpayer facing interactions.
Table of Contents
of Taxpayer Discrimination

) Purpose. This IRM provides guidance for managers and employees in providing reasonable accommodations and language assistance to Scope and The IRS goal and objective are to prevent discrimination of taxpayers in programs and activities. (
) Audience. The audience for this IRM is all managers and employees with taxpayer facing interactions. (
) Policy Owner. The Civil Rights Unit, is under the Office of Equity, Diversity and Inclusion. (
) Program Owner. The Civil Rights Unit is the office responsible for the external civil rights program. (
) The following authorities are applicable to this IRM: • Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of

) IRS policy requires that all necessary actions be taken to ensure members the public with disabilities have equal access to its programs, activities, services. The IRS also commits through its Taxpayer Bill of Rights which vides the right to quality service, to provide prompt, courteous, and profes- sional assistance to taxpayers, including those who lack a full command of English language. (

) The Chief Diversity Officer annually evaluates civil rights compliance within Service and its assisted programs to ensure that taxpayers are not Management to discrimination based on race, color, national origin (including limited proﬁciency), sex, and disability. Additional bases such as parental status religion are protected in educational programs and activities provided by Service. The evaluation of the programs is shared with the respective units to help ensure the achievement of civil rights compliance throughout Service and its assisted programs. (

) The evaluation of civil rights compliance within the Service and its assisted programs is comprised of an assessment of the physical accessibility of Controls facility where services or programs are provided, notiﬁcation of taxpayer and the provision of reasonable accommodations and language assistance individuals with limited English proﬁciency. (
) Key terms and deﬁnitions are listed below: a. Disability - a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits and Terms more major life activities.

Major Life Activity - Basic activities most people can perform with little no difficulty, such as walking, seeing, hearing, speaking, thinking, com- municating and interacting with others. c. Reasonable Accommodation - a change or adjustment, needed by a taxpayer with a disability to effectively participate in, and access IRS programs, activities or services which does not cause a fundamental al- teration, or an undue administrative or ﬁnancial burden. d. Limited English Proﬁciency (LEP) - Describes individuals who do not speak English as their primary language, and have limited ability to speak, write, or understand English. e. Meaningful Access - Language assistance that results in accurate, and effective communications especially for individuals with LEP. (

) The Internal Revenue Service prohibits discrimination against taxpayers on race, color, national origin (including limited English proﬁciency), sex, religion, disability and age in its programs, activities and services. Additional Taxpayers bases, such as sexual orientation and status as a parent, apply in education and training programs conducted by the IRS. Similarly, entities to which agencies grant federal ﬁnancial assistance must comply and prevent nation in their programs, activities, and services. Executive Order

requires that all federal agencies take reasonable steps to provide access to their own federally conducted activities. A federally conducted program or activity is, in simple terms, anything a Federal Agency does. from employment, there are two major categories of federally conducted programs or activities covered by the regulation: a. Programs or activities involving general public contact as part of Agency operations (telephone contacts, office walk-ins, or interviews) the public’s use of Agency facilities. b. Programs or activities directly administered for program beneﬁciaries participants (programs that provide federal services or beneﬁts). (

) Taxpayers with a disability may request a reasonable accommodation and those with limited English proﬁciency may request language assistance to access Agency programs and services. Requested accommodations and language assistance must be provided by the Agency or recipients of federal ﬁnancial assistance at no cost to the taxpayer. The Department of Justice consistently interpreted Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of

, and its regula- tions to require recipients of federal ﬁnancial assistance to provide access to individuals with limited English proﬁciency. Federal ﬁnancial assis- tance includes, but is not limited to, grants and loans of federal funds, grants or donations of federal property, training, detail of federal personnel, or any agreement, or arrangement which has as one of its purposes the provision assistance. Prevention of Taxpayer Discrimination
) Under Section
of the Rehabilitation Act of

a taxpayer with a disability may request a reasonable accommodation to access or participate in Agency programs, activities, or services, or another authorized individual may make such a request on his or her behalf. The taxpayer does not have to use the words “reasonable accommodation” when making their request. The request may be verbal or in writing and does not usually require medical documenta- tion.

Under Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 a taxpayer with a may request a reasonable accommodation to access or participate in Agency programs, activities, or services, or another authorized individual may make such a request on his or her behalf. The taxpayer does not have to use the words “reasonable accommodation” when making their request. The request may be verbal or in writing and does not usually require medical documenta-
vision impairment. While the taxpayer did not use the term “reasonable accommodation,” the taxpayer indicated a need to have the service delivered in a different manner due to a disability. (

) When a taxpayer with a disability requests a reasonable accommodation, medical documentation should not be requested. If the requested tion cannot be provided, then an effective alternative accommodation should be provided. However, there may be limited instances when medical tation may be necessary to determine whether an effective alternative accommodation can be provided. Prior to requesting the taxpayer’s medical documentation, it is recommended that you contact the IRS Civil Rights Unit phone at
or email: edi.crd.ra@irs.gov . The IRS Civil Rights is available to provide training and technical assistance about the reasonable accommodation requirements for taxpayers. (
) Except as outlined in (
) and (

) below, when a taxpayer with a disability makes a request for reasonable accommodation or modiﬁcation of an accommodation, the Agency should provide the requested accommodation modiﬁcation, or, when appropriate, an effective alternative accommodation. (
) In instances where the requested accommodation or modiﬁcation may mentally alter the nature of the program, or impose an undue ﬁnancial and administrative burden on the Agency. Section
of the Rehabilitation Act of

does not require agencies to provide the requested reasonable accom- modation. The burden of proving there is an undue ﬁnancial and burden falls on the Agency. However, the Agency may be required to provide the taxpayer an effective alternative accommodation. (

) Contact your manager and the IRS Civil Rights Unit immediately to possible reasonable accommodations before denying a taxpayer’s request reasonable accommodation or modiﬁcation. An employee should not deny a request for reasonable accommodation before contacting the IRS Civil Unit to discuss possible effective alternative accommodations. (

) If the provision of the requested accommodation will pose a direct threat to health and safety of others, the Agency is not required to grant the dation. When determining whether an individual poses a direct threat to the health or safety of others, the Agency must make an individualized assess- ment, based on reasonable judgment that relies on current medical or on the best available objective evidence, to determine:
the nature, duration, and severity of the risk
the probability that the potential injury will actually occur
whether reasonable modiﬁcations of policies, practices, or procedures the provision of auxiliary aids or services will mitigate the risk Internal Revenue Manual

) When a taxpayer with a disability requests a reasonable accommodation, medical documentation should not be requested. If the requested accommoda- tion cannot be provided, then an effective alternative accommodation should be provided. However, there may be limited instances when medical documen- tation may be necessary to determine whether an effective alternative accommodation can be provided. Prior to requesting the taxpayer’s medical documentation, it is recommended that you contact the IRS Civil Rights Unit by phone at
or email: edi.crd.ra@irs.gov . The IRS Civil Rights Unit is available to provide training and technical assistance about the reasonable accommodation requirements for taxpayers.

Equal Employment Opportunity and Example: Due to a recent pandemic, the Agency requires that all taxpayers face mask when entering its facility as the face mask is the only measure available to mitigate the direct threat to the health and others. As an accommodation, a taxpayer with a disability requests s/he enter the facility without a face mask because of an spiratory condition. Based on current medical knowledge, and the unavailability of existing alternative methods that would help risk of having the taxpayer enter into the facility without a face Agency is not required to grant the requested accommodation the taxpayer would pose a direct threat to the health or safety of However, the Agency will take steps to provide an effective accommodation to provide the service needed by the taxpayer. For assistance with making the determination on what constitutes a threat to the health and safety of others, contact the IRS Civil Rights phone at
or email: edi.crd.ra@irs.gov. (

ages/RAfo
P.aspx. (

) Limited English Proﬁciency (LEP) taxpayers must be provided access to our products and services. Language is an aspect of national Accessibility and thus, any laws that prohibit discrimination based on national origin discrimination based on language. (
) Executive Order

requires that each Federal Agency examine the services it provides, and develop and implement a system by which LEP persons can meaningfully access those services. This meaningful access be provided in an accurate, timely and effective way, and at no cost to taxpayer. The Executive Order can be viewed at: executive-order-
) IRS Policy Statement

, Commitment to assist non-English speaking payers understand their tax obligations, states, “The IRS is committed to viding top quality service to each taxpayer, including those who lack a full command of the English language.” The policy also states, “Our have the essential tools necessary to interact appropriately with our taxpayer base.” Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
N

Due to a recent pandemic, the Agency requires that all taxpayers wear a face mask when entering its facility as the face mask is the only safety measure available to mitigate the direct threat to the health and safety of others. As an accommodation, a taxpayer with a disability requests that s/he enter the facility without a face mask because of an underlying re

spiratory condition. Based on current medical knowledge, and the unavailability of existing alternative methods that would help mitigate the risk of having the taxpayer enter into the facility without a face mask, the Agency is not required to grant the requested accommodation because the taxpayer would pose a direct threat to the health or safety of others. However, the Agency will take steps to provide an effective alternative accommodation to provide the service needed by the taxpayer.

of Taxpayer Discrimination

) Every IRS employee has an obligation to comply with Executive Order and other mandates regarding language access for limited English for taxpayers. If a taxpayer identiﬁes a need for language assistance, it is the Meaningful gation of the Agency to provide the assistance. (
) Guidance for implementing the Language Services (LS) Program the Agency can be found in IRM
, Multilingual Initiative, IRS Guidance for Services: Services This IRM contains information on how to obtain verbal interpretation written translation services, and more. (

) Generally, the IRS provides language interpreter (oral) services through bilingual staff or over-the-phone interpreter (OPI) services. The Multilingual Language Access Agency Services Branch administers the OPI contract and handles all questions and issues regarding the OPI contract. Each business unit has its own policy and procedures for use of OPI services. It is important that you follow your business unit’s procedures for the provision of language assis- tance. (
) For more information on the OPI service and resources including the OPI Sheet, list of OPI representatives, and OPI tools, you can visit: irsnet.gov/sites/witaxforms/Pages/MAS/LPTS/OPI/Home.aspx. (

) The Agency is responsible for offering qualiﬁed interpreter services. An preter must be competent and have knowledge in both languages of the of Family/Friends as relevant terms or concepts being discussed. The Agency should avoid Interpreters untrained volunteers, or family members, children, and friends of an with limited English proﬁciency as interpreters, because it is difficult to that they will interpret accurately. (

) For English translations contact the Linguistic Policy, Tools, and Services Section, of the Multilingual and Agency Services Branch, Tax Forms & Translation tions Division, in Wage and Investment, Media & Publications. Translations performed either by internal employees or external contractors in several languages such as: • French • German • Italian • Portuguese • Various African languages • Arabic • Iranian Farsi • Spanish (

) Translation, quality review, and proofreading assistance may include any of following tasks: a. writing a summary translation of a source document b. reading documents aloud while the requestor takes notes c. reading documents to pinpoint vital information No.

) Part of preventing taxpayer discrimination is understanding the complaint process. Although business units are encouraged to attempt resolution of taxpayer complaints, those attempts should be in addition to informing the taxpayer of their right to contact the Civil Rights Unit (CRU) to ﬁle a Efforts of the business unit should not replace the taxpayer’s right to contact CRU. (

) Any person who believes that he or she has been discriminated based on race, color, sex, national origin, disability, age or reprisal, in programs or File a ties by the Internal Revenue Service may ﬁle a complaint. Be sure you know who can ﬁle a complaint, when a taxpayer should be referred to the Civil Rights Unit, how a taxpayer may ﬁle a complaint, and the authority covering the process. (

) Knowing when to refer a taxpayer’s complaint to the Civil Rights Unit (CRU) important. Taxpayers should be referred to CRU if the taxpayer believes that Refer a an IRS employee mistreated them because of any of the following bases: to the Civil color, national origin (including limited English proﬁciency), disability, reprisal, sex, age or religion. Additional bases such as sexual orientation and status are applicable in educational programs or activities conducted by the IRS. Certain taxpayer comments such as the following should trigger a to CRU: a. “I’ve been discriminated against and want to ﬁle a complaint.” b. “I was denied service, or I was refused service because of (race, sex, other civil rights basis). Where do I go?” c. “I have a disability and want to ﬁle a complaint because they wouldn’t provide an accommodation.” (
) For more information on when to refer a taxpayer to the CRU view the full advisory – When to Refer Taxpayers to CRU: Sit
ages/TP-Discrim-Complaints.aspx. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) A person who believes that he or she has been discriminated against may a complaint individually, through an authorized representative or on behalf a Complaint speciﬁc class of persons. The complaint may be ﬁled electronically, by audiotape, in braille, or in an alternative medium. Oral complaints may be if the complainant is unable to write, and no one is available to write the gations on his or her behalf. (

) A taxpayer wishing to ﬁle a complaint of discrimination involving any of IRS federally ﬁnancially assisted or conducted programs should be directed to submit their complaint in writing to the Civil Rights Unit. A taxpayer may a written complaint or complete Form
, Civil Rights Complaint: http:// publish.no.irs.gov/cat

) The complaint can be mailed to the following address: Internal Revenue Service Office of Equity, Diversity and Inclusion Civil Rights Unit, Room
Constitution Avenue, NW Washington, DC
Complaints may also be sent by email: edi.civil.rights@irs.gov. (
) To ﬁle a complaint online, a complaint form is available at: gov/cat

) The Civil Rights Unit will be responsible for conducting inquiries into complaints of discrimination. An inquiry will ordinarily include interviews with Investigations the complainant, grant recipient, employees/volunteers, other witness (es), review of pertinent records, the facility of the grant recipient (if applicable), consideration of the evidence gathered, and defenses asserted by the or the grant recipient.
